You are here:

SALESFORCE HELP
DOCS
REVENUE LIFECYCLE MANAGEMENT
Products

Products are all the items and services that you sell to customers. Products can also be non-sellable. There are two types of products: simple products and bundled products. Simple products don’t have an associated product hierarchy while bundled products generally have one. Bundled products are a group of products that are sold together as one unit.

REQUIRED EDITIONS
Available in: Lightning Experience
Available in: Enterprise, Unlimited, and Developer editions

Simple and bundled products are further classified into configurable or static products depending on whether you can configure products during run time or not.

The value of the ‘Product Type’ field dictates whether the product is simple or bundled. The value of the ‘ConfigureDuringSale’ field dictates whether the product is static or configurable. The Product Type and ConfigureDuring Sale fields are available during product creation.

Hazelnut flavored instant coffee is an example of a static simple product. However, French roast coffee grounds, where users can select between medium roast or dark roast are an example of a simple configurable product. A travel kit that contains a shampoo, conditioner, body wash, body lotion, toothbrush, and toothpaste is an example of a static product bundle. A seller can sell a laptop with a pre-installed operating system and a free 15-month antivirus subscription. The seller can additionally give customers an option to purchase an extended warranty plan and wireless headphones with the laptop. The laptop with all required and optional components is an example of a configurable product bundle.

The table lists the various combinations of Product Type and Configure During Sale and the resultant products. The table also lists the possible child product components for every product.

PRODUCT TYPE	CONFIGURE DURING SALE	PRODUCT	CHILD COMPONENTS
None	Not Allowed or None	Static simple product	None
Allowed	Configurable simple product	None
Bundle	Not Allowed or None	Static product bundle	
Static simple
Static bundle

Allowed	Configurable product bundle	
Static simple
Static bundle
Configurable simple
Configurable bundle
Important Things to Note About Static Product Bundles
You can optionally add Product Group (1) components to the static bundle hierarchy.
If you delete a group, all components under the group, such as products and product classifications, are deleted.
Add only static simple products or static bundled products as child components of static bundled products. You can’t add configurable simple products or configurable bundle products as child components of static bundled products.
When you add child components to a static product bundle, make sure that the field Include component by default is selected on the child components. Also ensure that the field Allow Quantity Changes isn’t selected on the child components.
If your static simple product is based on a product classification, then all attributes for all components in the static bundle must have default values.
Important Things to Note About Configurable Product Bundles
Groups are mandatory components in a configurable product bundle. Child components must be added only under Groups and not directly under the root product.
You can add multiple product components or one product classification under a product group.
When you delete a group, all components under the group, such as products and product classifications, are deleted.
You can add simple and bundled products of type static or configurable as child components of a configurable bundle.
Create Simple Products
Simple products are products that don’t have a hierarchy. Their product type field is ‘None’. You can set the value of the Configure During Sale field to Not Allowed, or Allowed depending on whether you’re creating static simple products or configurable simple products.
Conversion Of Simple Products
You can convert a static simple product to a configurable simple product when you want to make the product configurable during run time. You can convert a configurable simple product to a static simple product when you don’t want the product to be configurable during run time. You can change a static simple product to a configurable simple product or vice versa. However, you can’t change a simple product (static or configurable) to a bundled product (static or configurable) and vice versa.
Product Selling Model
Product selling models define how you sell products. The models can be one time, term-defined, or evergreen. For example, a phone is sold one time or in a term of 12 months, however the cellular data plan is billed monthly in an evergreen model until the user cancels it. Product selling model is an optional feature.
Product Relationships
Bundle products consist of components such as groups, products, and product classifications. These components are related to each other through product relationships.
Create Bundled Products
Bundled products are a group of products that are sold together as one unit. You can create static or configurable bundled products. For static products, you can’t add or remove child products, alter product quantities, or configure product attributes at run time. For configurable products, you can add or remove child products, alter product quantities, and configure product attributes at run time.
Creation of a Bundled Product Structure
After you create a bundled product (static or configurable), use the Structure tab in the bundled product to add child components such as groups, products, and product classifications.
Override Product Component Attributes in Bundles
You can override the attributes of product components in the context of the product bundle.
Include or Exclude Picklist Values in Overridden Product Attributes
Override product attributes to create the override in the context of a product bundle. To include or exclude specific picklist values for overridden product attributes of the data type picklist, use Include or Exclude Picklist Values. The included picklist values are available at run time while excluded picklist values are unavailable at run time.
Local Cardinality and Group Cardinality
A product bundle is a set of products sold together. You can define cardinality for every product in the bundle. Cardinality ensures you specify the right quantities in the cart: not too many, and not too few.
Validate the Product Definition
It’s easy to lose count of the number of components in the bundle when the product bundle has product components with their own hierarchy. Additionally, it’s easy to miss assigning a default value to every attribute for every product component in large static product bundles and simple products. Finally, you want to be sure that the number of distinct products under a group are within the permissible group cardinality values. Use Validate Product Definition to check for all these conditions on-demand.
Exclude Bundle Components
When you want to make a group of products, or specific products unavailable for selection in the run time, you can exclude them from the product bundle. Excluding a product or a group doesn’t delete the product or group from the bundle hierarchy. It just hides or excludes the product or group from the list of available products in the run time. The exclusion is in the context of the root product bundle that you’re in. The product or group continues to be available under other product bundles.
Conversion Of Bundle Products
You can change a static bundled product to a configurable bundled product when you want to configure the product bundle during run time. You can change a configurable bundled product to a static bundled product when you don’t want users to configure the product bundle during run time. You can change a static bundled product to a configurable bundled product or vice versa. However, you can’t change a simple product (static or configurable) to a bundled product (static or configurable) and vice versa.
Configure Product Attributes
Products that are based on a product classification inherit all the attributes from the product classification. You can configure the inherited attributes to make them product-specific. You can override the configured and inherited attributes in the context of a product bundle.
Include or Exclude Picklist Values in a Product Attribute
A product that’s based on a product classification, inherits all the product classification attributes including any included or excluded picklist values. To include or exclude specific picklist values for product attributes of the data type picklist, use Include or Exclude Picklist Values. The included picklist values are available at run time while excluded picklist values are unavailable at run time.
